title: Former police officer who fatally shot woman in her own home was booked for murder
text:
Tarrant County Jail via AP





A former Texas police officer who shot and killed a woman in her own home over the weekend was booked at the Tarrant County Jail and charged with murder on Monday evening local time, according to local news reports.

Former Fort Worth police officer Aaron Dean shot Atatiana Jefferson, 28, through a window of her home while she was playing video games with her nephew.

Fort Worth police chief Edwin Kraus said at a news conference Monday that the department intended to fire Dean for inappropriate conduct, but Dean resigned from the position earlier Monday.

The shooting comes after white former Dallas police officer Amber Guyger, 31, was sentenced to 10 years in prison earlier this month, for fatally shooting her black upstairs neighbor, Botham Jean, after mistaking his apartment as her own and thinking he was an intruder.

A former Texas police officer, who shot and killed a woman in her own home over the weekend, was booked at the Tarrant County Jail and charged with murder, on Monday evening local time, according to reports. A reporter at local news station KDFW first tweeted the news. Local news KTXA-TV confirmed the report.

Former Fort Worth police officer Aaron Dean shot Atatiana Jefferson, 28, through her bedroom window while she was playing video games with her nephew. Body camera footage released by the police department revealed that Dean did not identify himself as police before opening fire. Dean resigned from his position earlier Monday.

Dean was arrested at around 6 p.m., and was booked at the jail, according to a statement from Fort Worth Police Department.

"We feel and understand your anger and disappointment and we stand by you as we work together to make Fort Worth a better place for all of us," the police department wrote in the statement.

Fox4 reporter Macy Jenkins tweeted that Dean posted bail at 9 p.m. Monday night.

Fort Worth police chief Edwin Kraus said at a news conference Monday that the department intended to fire Dean for violating the department's standards on use of force and de-escalation, condemning his actions as inappropriate.

"Nobody looked at that video and said there's any doubt this officer acted inappropriately," Kraus told reporters. "I get it. We're trying to train our officers better, we're trying to shore up our policies, trying to ensure they act and react the way the citizens intend them to — that they act and react with a servant's heart, instead of a warrior's heart."

Jefferson's family issued a statement following Dean's arrest, saying they are "relieved" to see that he had been arrested and charged with murder.

"We need to see this through to a vigorous prosecution and appropriate sentencing," the Jefferson family said in the statement. "The City of Fort Worth has much work to do to reform a brutal culture of policing."

Read more: Fort Worth police fatally shot a woman inside her own home after a neighbor reported that her front door was open

CBS News reported that Jefferson had moved into the home to take care of her mother, who was recently hospitalized, as well as her nephews, including 8-year-old Zion, who she was with the night she was killed.

Family attorney Lee Merritt said during a news conference, per CBS News, that Jefferson heard the police officers "prowling and whispering" outside, and she went to the window to investigate. It was at this moment in the body cam footage that one officer said Jefferson, "Put your hands up, show me your hands," before a single shot was fired.

Jefferson was pronounced dead at the scene.

"She was enjoying a life in her home, where no one would have expected her life to be in harm's way, especially not at the hands of a civil servant who has taken an oath to serve and protect," Jefferson's sister Ashley Carr said during the news conference.

The shooting comes after the sentencing of another white police officer who had shot and killed a black victim in a high-profile incident. Former Dallas police officer Amber Guyger, 31, was sentenced to 10 years in prison earlier this month, for fatally shooting her upstairs neighbor, Botham Jean, after mistaking his apartment as her own and thinking he was an intruder.
